PREVIEW: BoJ Minutes from December 20th-21st meeting due at 2350GMT/1750CST/0750HKT
content:
The BoJ are to release the meeting minutes from the December 20th-21st meeting, where the central bank maintained QQE with yield curve control policy and kept NIRP at -0.10% as expected. At the meeting, the BoJ kept its economic assessment unchanged in which it stated the economy was expanding moderately, while it raised its assessment on capex and view of consumption.

The decision on QQE with Yield Curve Control was made by 8-1 vote with Kataoka the dissenter again, as he called for buying JGBs so yield for duration of 10yrs and longer decline, while he also stated that the BoJ should make it clear it will ease if achieving the price target is delayed by domestic factors. Furthermore, Kataoka also opposed the assessment of CPI and stated there is a small chance of prices gathering pace towards the 2% target.

Today’s release is not expected to have a significant effect on Japanese asset classes considering that the decision failed to impact markets, while there was also a more recent meeting earlier this week in which the BoJ also kept policy unchanged as expected and maintained all Real GDP and Core CPI forecasts in the Outlook Report.

EU

- The bank repeated that if the outlook becomes less favourable or financial conditions become inconsistent with progress towards achieving inflation, stands ready to increase the asset purchase programme in terms of size and duration.

RBC on the ECB
content: We continue to think it likely that the ECB’s preference will be for a smooth rather than abrupt exit from QE. After the September expiry, a short tapering period, which Draghi seemed to hint in the Q&A was his preference, of three months to wind purchases down to zero remains the most likely scenario, in our view. With Draghi continuing to emphasise the current language on sequencing we remain comfortable with our call, reiterated in advance of the meeting, that we won’t see the first rate rise from the ECB until Q3 2019.

subject: EUROPEAN PRELIMINARY CASH EQUITY CLOSE: EURO STOXX 50 (-0.56%), FTSE 100 (-0.36%), DAX (-0.96%), CAC (-0.32%), IBEX (+0.25%), FTSE MIB (+0.26%), SMI (-0.71)
Barclays on the ECB
content:
As broadly expected, there were no policy announcements at the January policy meeting and the monetary policy statement remained unchanged. FX volatility is a concern for the GC and represents a downside risk to the macroeconomic outlook, but upside risks related to the momentum of the cyclical expansion were also stressed. Although President Draghi emphasised the forward guidance on rates, and in particular the reference to “well past the end of net asset purchases”, we still believe that under our forecast of a 2.5% growth rate this year and some progress on inflation, the ECB will end its APP in September and proceed with a first depo rate hike in December. 

President Draghi delivered a very bullish view of euro area growth, even if inflation remains uninspiring. He referred several times to the robust pace of economic expansion, which accelerated in Q4 17. As a result, the Governing Council has strengthened its confidence that inflation will gradually converge towards the inflation objective of 2%. Both domestic demand and net exports remain supportive of growth. Despite the recent euro appreciation, stronger-than-expected global growth provides an impetus to EA exports, in spite of the strength of the currency. We forecast euro area growth in 2018 at 2.5% (ECB 2.3%) and expect the ECB to upgrade growth close to our forecast at the next ECB meeting in March.

At the same time, President Draghi delivered a dovish policy message, showing some concerns about the recent euro appreciation and rising market expectations about future policy rate hikes. He went as far as stating that, based on current data, he saw very little chance that interest rates could be raised this year. Similarly, president Draghi also emphasised the importance of being “well past the end of net asset purchases” for the first rate hike. We think that this message was aimed primarily at watering down the recent shift in market expectations and limiting the upside pressure on the the currency.

President Draghi stated that the discussion on amendments to forward guidance “has not really started”, in Draghi’s own words. He explained that the account of the December meeting may have been mis-interpreted, suggesting that the discussion on forward guidance (FG) would start soon, but not meaning that the forward guidance would be adjusted soon. Our view is that an adjustment of the FG will likely be announced in April, will disentangle the exit from negative rates from the hiking cycle, and link the hiking cycle to actual progress in the path of inflation toward the ECB target. President Draghi repeated the three main conditions required to start removing monetary accommodation, namely 1)  inflation should be on a path that reaches the target in the medium term; 2) the ECB needs to have confidence on the degree of convergence towards the target; and 3) convergence has to be self-supported (ie, it has to be there without monetary policy support). Moreover, once adjustment has progressed enough, monetary policy will still stay very accommodative, as there will be asset reinvestments and interest rates will stay low.

President Draghi also noted that since the last meeting, the expected path of interest rates has increased and the euro has appreciated. He admitted that the GC discussed this issue and considered there were three reasons: 1) further improvement in the economic situation; 2) increased market sensitivity to perceived changes; 3) non-ECB communications about the currency (in reference to the US). He was particularly vocal about recent statements on FX markets (from US officials), which are perceived as being non-compliant with the terms of reference agreed in Washington at the IMFC meeting.

President Draghi clarified that there will still need to be a discussion within the GC about the end of QE, therefore mentioning three options to be discussed: 1) sudden stop of net asset purchases; 2) extension; or 3) gradual tapering. We think the GC will opt during the summer for the sudden stop, based on economic strength and further progress toward the inflation target.

Asked about the compliance of the APP with the capital key rule, he stated that the rule applies to the stock of asset purchases, not to monthly gross purchases, which can deviate quite substantially from the capital key because of the composition of the portfolio in terms of maturities and short-term market conditions. Asked about financial stability risks related to negative interest rates for a long period of time, Vice President Constancio answered that there was no evidence of overstretched valuations, with the exception of some high yield bonds and commercial real estate markets in some member states, which have deployed macro-prudential tools to address these problems.

Our Baseline ECB Call:

After the January ECB meeting, we maintain our baseline policy path for the ECB, namely: 1) an adjustment of the forward guidance on rates, to be decided at the April meeting, focusing on the future path for rates and disentangling the exit from negative rates and the hiking cycle; 2) the end of the asset purchase programme in September, although re-investment of maturing securities would likely continue at least until 2020; and 3) a first increase in the depo rate by 20bp in December, followed by another increase in March 2019 that would leave the policy rate at zero at least until end-2019. Admittedly, further meaningful appreciation of the euro would clearly put our call on the ECB at risk, as it would imply a more gradual normalisation – on a multilateral basis the euro has appreciated by c. 9% since February 2017.

subject: PREVIEW: US to sell USD 28bln 7-year notes at 1800 GMT (1300 ET)
content:
The US Treasury will sell a total of USD 103.0bln during the week, with USD 104.5bln set to mature at month-end.

Shorter dated Treasury yields have continued to move higher over the past month, and as a result TD Securities expect 5-year & 7-year coupons to be 25bps higher in this auction cycle compared with December’s.

It is also worth noting that CME Fed Fund Futures are pricing in just shy of a 75% chance of a 25bps Fed hike at its March meeting, with the same instrument currently pricing a 60% chance of 3 hikes this calendar year.

Last month’s shorter dated note auctions came in on the softer side, although the supply took place between Christmas and the turn of the year.

TD Securities notes that “the past 3 7-year auctions have tailed and the sector remains very rich on the curve. We are cautious about demand for 7s despite the recent rise in rates, and expect a softer reception.”

Societe Generale suggests that the current 7-year note is trading slightly cheap on asset swap versus old 7s compared with the previous two auctions and is trading fair on the curve versus 5s and 10s. the bank also believes that the 7Y sector does not have a clear setup for the upcoming auction from a relative value perspective. On a positive note, the cheaper outright level, with the current 7-year note yield above the 7-year auctions stop-out rate since April 2011, is a positive according to SocGen.

- High yield: Previous 2.370% (vs six-auction average of 2.180%)

content: The Greenback has huffed and puffed, but failed to mount any meaningful recovery after slumping to fresh multi-year lows against all and sundry. The US admin had ample opportunity to tweak weak Dollar language and ease trade war tensions, but declined and the DXY duly declined further towards the next tech supports just below 88.500 and above 88.250 (88.423 is a Fib retracement level and 88.282 the 200 DMA) despite attempts by some EU officials to turn the tide (SNB President Jordan and Italian Finance Minister for example). ECB’s Draghi did not expressly comment about Eur strength, though did repeat concern about currency market volatility and GC worries about a potential change in US policy, so Eur/Usd extended gains through more chart resistance on the way to and through 1.2500 (reaching 1.2535 at one stage and surpassing the ECB event risk range inferred by options in the process). Cable recovered 1.4300+ status and almost hit 1.4350 and Usd/Jpy hit fresh lows below 109.00 and not far off key ‘support’ seen at 108.50. Usd/Chf lost 0.9300 regardless of the aforementioned Swiss CB intervention threat and eyeing the 0.9251 Black Monday low next, while Usd/Cad shrugged off negative NAFTA headlines and mixed Canadian retail sales data to trade sub-1.2300. Aud/Usd is back on track to reclaim 0.8100 (vs 2017’s 0.8125 best), but Nzd/Usd continued to struggle just above 0.7350 (vs Wednesday’s 0.7400-plus high) following Q4 CPI miss overnight. Usd/Cnh collapsed again after a short squeeze late in the Asian session as the Dollar’s losing streak resumed and shows little signing of ending.

content: Bunds briefly breached 160.11 tech support amidst the upbeat growth comments from ECB’s Draghi and with a 10k lot sell order seen on a break of 160.30 to post a new 159.97 base (-43 ticks vs +35 ticks at the fresh base set just before his press conference, while his failure to address or decision not to arrest the Eur’s appreciation has left the single currency free to rally further vs the weak Usd. 1.2517 next ‘resistance’ on the charts (Fib leve) vs circa 1.2500 top, so far.

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: Another day, another rout in the USD index, as Asian participants were able to react to yesterday’s comments from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin
content:
Another day, another rout in the USD index, as Asian participants were able to react to yesterday’s comments from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin

  • A majority of European bourses (Eurostoxx 50 are trading with minor gains, aside from the DAX (-0.1%) which has faltered amid the rising EUR
  • Looking ahead, highlights include the ECB rate decision and press conference, US weekly jobs, Japanese CPI

ASIA

A subdued tone was seen across Asia stock markets following a lacklustre lead from Wall St, where the Nasdaq underperformed on tech weakness and most major indices finished negative despite hitting fresh intraday all-time highs. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) were lower in which Japanese exporters felt the brunt after USD/JPY briefly slipped to below 109.00, while losses in Australia were stemmed as miners benefited from the recent USD-induced commodity rally. Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were cautious after the PBoC skipped open market operations and amid trade war concerns due to protectionist messages from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Commerce Secretary Ross at Davos. Finally, 10yr JGBs weakened on spill-over selling from their US counterparts and with demand also dampened by weaker 20yr auction results.

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea is said to be calling for rapid improvement in North-South relations and said it will smash all challenges against reunification of the Korean peninsula. (KCNA)

EQUITIES

A majority of European bourses (Eurostoxx 50 are trading with minor gains, aside from the DAX (-0.1%) which has faltered amid the rising EUR weighing on exporters. Tech names the underperforming sector this morning having taken the impetus from their US counterparts. Additionally, in terms of stock specific, Aryzta is the worst performing stock after the company announced a profit warning, while Smith and Nephew sit at the top of the FTSE 100 following a broker upgrade at JP Morgan Chase.

FX

Another day, another rout in the USD index, as Asian participants were able to react to yesterday’s comments from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin who stated that USD weakness is good for the US in the short term. Overnight, the USD printed a fresh 3yr low after dipping through 89.00 and moving towards key support situated at 88.25 (50% Fib retrace of rally from 72.65 to 109.89).  Subsequently, GBP continued its stellar gains to move above 1.43, while USD/CHF briefly broke through the 94.25/50 support area which has been in place for 2yrs. However, the USD has found some slight reprieve amid talk of suspected FX intervention in Asian currencies (CNH and JPY) and as such has reclaimed 89.00. As many begin to ask the question of potential currency wars, participants will look to Draghi’s post rate decision press conference on whether he will address recent EUR strength. Elsewhere, NZD had been hit by much weaker than expected Q4 NZ inflation data, which has prompted analysts to push back their rate hike expectations to mid-19. NOK relatively unfazed by the latest Norges Decision which saw the bank stand pat on rates and reiterate the findings of the December analysis.


FIXED INCOME

Core bonds have retreated a bit further from opening/earlier session peaks, with Bunds down to 160.37 (-3 ticks vs +30 ticks at the Eurex peak) and eyeing recent lows only a few ticks lower that have continued to thwart fixed bears and protect serious attacks on the January/2018 base. Gilts have now been as low as 122.81 (-5 ticks vs +24 ticks at the Liffe best), while US Treasuries are off overnight peaks amidst some 10 year selling. UST futures are still holding a firmer line and re-flattening after reverse moves on Wednesday, with perhaps even more focus than usual on the 7 year note auction given its normal popularity with foreign buyers, but amidst the broad Dollar demise and the trade protectionism tit for tat being waged in Davos. 

 

COMMODITIES

Onward and upwards for commodity prices which have benefitted from the aforementioned USD weakness. Brent crude futures briefly took out the USD 71.00 handle, in terms of levels to the upside, 71.66 (50% Fib retrace of decline from USD 116.1 to USD 27.23 may provide near term resistance. Elsewhere, gold rose to levels not seen since mid-2013 and copper also rallied despite the risk averse tone, as the greenback’s woes solely fuelled gains across the complex.

FX Morning Colour: extreme Usd selling abates somewhat
content: The DXY and Dollar in general has benefited from some short covering, with Usd/Jpy, Usd/Myr (after an expected 25 bp Malaysian rate hike) and Usd/Cnh all bought in late Asian trade by a variety of accounts. The index is back above 0.8900 amidst broad recovery gains and retests of big figure levels that were hit or surpassed amidst the wave of all round Usd selling yesterday and overnight. However, the partial recovery and respite looks fragile as US officials maintain that the weaker Greenback is good for trade, albeit Treasury Secretary Mnuchin adding that its value will reflect healthy economic fundamentals in the longer term. Eur/Usd has eased back to pivot 1.2400 vs almost 1.2460 highs ahead of the ECB meeting, Cable is back under 1.4300 and Usd/Jpy above 109.00 from 108.75 at one stage. Usd/Cad has reclaimed 1.2300+ status as NAFTA discussions continue and Usd/Chf has bounced over 0.9400. Aud/Usd just fell short of the 0.8125 peak from 2017 and is currently sub-0.8100, but holding up better than its Nzd peer (below 0.7350 vs 0.7400+ at best) with the Kiwi hit by much weaker than expected Q4 NZ inflation data. Elsewhere, Eur/Nok is weaker circa 9.5800 awaiting the Norges Bank rate verdict (no change expected).

Bunds: catch-up gains ahead of Ifo and ECB
content: A corrective gap higher off the Eurex open, but no further advances from the initial 160.70 print (so far) for the 10 year German debt future as attention turns to the latest Ifo survey and ECB policy meeting. Consensus for the main Ifo business readings indicate some moderation, but the bias appears firmly to the upside of the median forecasts given ZEW beats and other robust data/upbeat economic projections. Moreover, the risk skew around the tone of the ECB statement and President Draghi’s press conference/Q&A seems more hawkish or at least less dovish, albeit balanced to acknowledge the impact of Eur strength on inflation. Hence, it looks like a fade rally day for Bunds and the core bond has already drifted back to a 160.57 low vs Wednesday’s 160.40 close.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: A subdued tone was seen across Asian stock markets following a lacklustre lead from Wall St
content:
• A subdued tone was seen across Asian stock markets following a lacklustre lead from Wall St
  • The greenback continued to languish after yesterday’s comments from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German IFO, Norwegian and ECB rate decisions, US weekly jobs, Japanese CPI

ASIA

A subdued tone was seen across Asia stock markets following a lacklustre lead from Wall St, where the Nasdaq underperformed on tech weakness and most major indices finished negative despite hitting fresh intraday all-time highs. ASX 200 (-0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.1%) were lower in which Japanese exporters felt the brunt after USD/JPY briefly slipped to below 109.00, while losses in Australia were stemmed as miners benefited from the recent USD-induced commodity rally. Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were cautious after the PBoC skipped open market operations and amid trade war concerns due to protectionist messages from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Commerce Secretary Ross at Davos. Finally, 10yr JGBs weakened on spill-over selling from their US counterparts and with demand also dampened by weaker 20yr auction results.

PBoC skipped open market operations for today to safeguard bank liquidity stability, while it stated that targeted RRR cut is to offset reverse repo demand. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3724 (Prev. 6.3916)

PBoC Governor Zhou was not re-elected into the CPPCC National Committee, which some reports speculated could be a sign of a looming retirement. (Newswires)

China Mofcom stated that China strongly opposes the US Trade Representative report which showed unilateralism and overlooks facts. Furthermore, it added that China doesn't want an escalation of trade dispute with the US and will take appropriate measures against unilateral moves. (Newswires)

South Korean GDP (Q4 P) Q/Q -0.2% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 1.5%); 1st contraction since 2008. (Newswires)
South Korean GDP (Q4 P) Y/Y 3.0% vs. Exp. 3.1% (Prev. 3.8%)

UK/EU

UK Transport Secretary and Brexit advocate Grayling said non-EU bilateral post-Brexit talks are progressing well. (Newswires)

UK Office for Budget Responsibility's Chote said the UK economy is 'weak and stable' and sees the chances of another recession in the next 5 years at 50%. (Newswires)

Finland reportedly warned the EU that it will not help fill the EUR 15bln Brexit budget hole. (Newswires)
 

FX

The greenback languished after yesterday’s comments from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin that the weaker USD is good for trade. This further added to the ongoing USD-dump and saw GBP/USD attempt a claim on the 1.4300 handle to the upside, while USD/JPY tested a breakdown of the 109.00 level and the USD-index briefly fell below 89.00 for the 1st time in over 3 years. Elsewhere, commodity-linked currencies were also underpinned by gains in energy and metals, although NZD/USD briefly took a dive after a miss on Q4 CPI data which led to speculation that market forecasts for a rate hike later this year would be pushed back.

New Zealand CPI (Q4) Q/Q 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires)
New Zealand CPI (Q4) Y/Y 1.6% vs. Exp. 1.9% (Prev. 1.9%)


COMMODITIES

Commodity prices extended on gains overnight with the advances fuelled by a weaker USD. As such, WTI crude futures rose above USD 66/bbl to print its highest since late-2014, while the latest comments from Saudi’s Oil Minister also suggested unlikelihood of a early exit from the output cut deal. Elsewhere, gold rose to levels not seen since mid-2013 and copper also rallied despite the risk averse tone, as the greenback’s woes solely fuelled gains across the complex.

Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said the oil glut could return if the market is out of balance for a few months and added it is highly unlikely that we will exit cuts in June. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

North Korea is said to be calling for rapid improvement in North-South relations and said it will smash all challenges against reunification of the Korean peninsula. (KCNA)

US President Trump has warned Turkey that an expansion of their military offence in Syria could lead to direct conflict with US forces. (Newswires)


US

Treasury prices fell on Wednesday after US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin endorsed a weak US dollar, resulting in the curve bear steepening. The steeper curve contributed to some modest widening of curve spreads (2s30s was slightly wider, as was 5s30s at settlement), however, 2s5s and 2s10s saw some (again, modest) narrowing. The US auctioned $34bln of 5-year notes in an average sale, tailing by 0.4bps despite better cover than the prior auction. Internals were mostly in-line with recent averages, though the auction was, perhaps, not as bad as some had feared given today’s steeper Treasury curve. US 10-Year T-Note futures settle 7 ticks lower at 122-06+.

US President Trump said infrastructure plan will total around USD 1.7tln and will be part of State of Union Address next Tuesday. (Newswires)

US President Trump told reporters he is open to the concept of giving DACA recipients citizenship in 10-12 years as part of immigration plan, while he added that immigration bill must include measures to curb family sponsorship of immigrants and a visa lottery system. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he would answer questions from Special Counsel Mueller under oath and tell him there was no collusion with Russia, while there were also reports that US Special Counsel Mueller team is to give President Trump potential interview topics. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks weaken after US pullback and ongoing trade concerns, while USD woes persist and NZD dives on weak CPI
content:
A subdued tone is seen across Asia stock markets following a lacklustre lead from Wall St, where the Nasdaq underperformed on tech weakness and most major indices finished negative despite hitting fresh intraday all-time highs. ASX 200 (-0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.9%) are lower with Japanese exporters feeling the brunt after USD/JPY briefly slipped to below 109.00, while losses in Australia have been stemmed as miners benefit from the recent USD-induced commodity rally. Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) are also downbeat after the PBoC skipped open market operations and amid trade war concerns due to protectionist messages from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin and Commerce Secretary Ross at Davos.

In FX markets, the greenback languishes after yesterday’s comments from US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin that the weaker USD is good for trade. This further added to the ongoing USD-dump and saw EUR/USD and GBP/USD reclaim the 1.2400 and 1.4200 handles respectively, while USD/JPY briefly slipped to below 109.00 for the first time since September. Elsewhere, commodity-linked currencies were also underpinned by gains in energy and metals, although NZD/USD then took a dive after a miss on Q4 CPI data which led to speculation that the market would have push back calls for a rate hike later this year.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower on spill-over selling from their US counterparts, with demand is also dampened ahead of a 20yr auction later.
